title: How many states will have reported 1,000 or more COVID-19 deaths as of 1 May 2020?
preds: Ohio is a toss up at this stage. It's probable based on their death rates, but frankly there are too many variables ranging from unpredictability of the virus, to poor accounting, etc. I'd say its more likely than not, but impossible to say with certainty.

As everyone has pointed out, OH is at 975 today. We all clearly did not understand the data entry process in OH, and I think the Covid Tracking Project does not either. (They have too many things to understand.) If you look at Ohio's official dashboard [1], specifically number of deaths, you will see that they retroactively change how many deaths occurred on past days. That makes sense; someone dies today, but it takes a few days for the tests results to come back saying they died of coronavirus. But the result is that the number of daily deaths recorded at CVT [2] is now completely wrong. For instance, the number of deaths on 20, 21, 22 April are 696, 735, 769 according to the official Ohio dashboard, but they are recorded as 509, 557, 610 at CVT. Given the poor quality of the data used to resolve this question, it is difficult to go to 100% on "more than 13", even though that will absolutely without a doubt be the truth on the ground in Ohio, and even the truth as reported by Ohio on 4 May. It may simply not be reported by CVT by 4 May. So I will hedge at 85%. (Up from 80%.) [1] https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/dashboards
[2] https://covidtracking.com/data/state/ohio
25 deaths in Ohio in 16 hours and it's more than 13 states. A gambit.
Ohio is likely to post over 25 deaths tomorrow

The following states have exceeded 1000 deaths: California
Connecticut
Florida
Georgia
Illinois
Indiana
Louisiana
Maryland
Massachusetts
Michigan
New Jersey
New York
Pennsylvania.  That is 13 exactly. Ohio is at 975 deaths right now, and so needs to increase by more than 25 for Friday to reach 1000 and put us into the more than 13 category. Ohio's death count has exceed 25 every day for the past week, so it seems highly likely to do so again.
975 is the final count for May 1 and won’t be updated before the 4th
looks like OH is going to cross 1000 mark.

Ohio is at 975 as of now. Last delta was +38 with a 5 day average of ~50.
That said, the swing in change could land at +/- 25
Going over looks likely, but not certain. https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/dashboards/current-trends
https://covid19.healthdata.org/united-states-of-america/ohio

Ohio needs less than 25 deaths tomorrow to stay below 1000. Technically, this has been the case in 2 of the last 10 days (over the last weekend). However, we now know that these cases were understated (hence the 138 case bump yesterday) and, besides, they fell on a weekend while tomorrow is Friday. Overall, not very likely. There is another chance of deaths staying below 1000 - if by May 4 (when the question will be resolved), the number is revised down. But this seems a very small chance (the revision has to be notable), so I'd ignore it.
It looks like Ohio will reach 1,000 deaths, pushing the total number of states to 13.
OH unfortunately will likely make the list.

Previous forecast:
0%
0%
0%
25% 
75% Ohio will record 38 more deaths today [1]. This means they need 25 more tomorrow to reach 1000, which is very likely. [1]https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/us/
Already 13, Ohio almost at 1000 so 14. state

As others have commented, it all depends on Ohio.  According to the Columbus Dispatch newspaper there were 75 deaths reported on one day that actually occurred over the previous three days.  That's a rate of increase of 25 per day. The the rate could very well moderate over the next two days (hopefully), or it could push over 1000.  It's kind of a coin flip.  But since 18% of the crowd has put chips on numbers that cannot be correct we all get a free bet.  You can beat the crowd without taking any risk.

Ohio is coming up hard on the outside and will probably push the number up to 14 in the next couple of days.  Still, yesterday's number was sort of unusual, so it may be a one-off late report of something or other.

Are or will hit 1000 (CA, Connecticut, Illinois, Louisiana, MA, Michigan, NJ, NY, Florida, Pennsylvania, Georgia, maryland, Indiana). Likely (Ohio) With Ohio adding about 140 deaths, ohio scrambles my previous prediction, and with 2 days to go in numbers, not just the one as believed there is actually a substantial chance that Ohio goes over and becomes the 14th state. Therefore updating the probabilities.
Ohio will bring the total to 14

As I stated in one of my previous forecast, if the care facilities are going to report their true death cause, it might radically change the numbers as up to 40% of the people are infected and often have a very low resistance. 
I’m back to >13 but it is hoping that the adjustments in the days after today will reflect the deaths in the care facilities.
Updating forecast; Washington, Colorado and Texas have not produced a sudden spike in death toll, but Ohio had a sudden spike of 138 new cases, so most likely the total number of states will be >13.
Revising due to the high value reported in Ohio.
Because of the recent spike in deaths in Ohio.
One-off spike with Ohio makes me want to revise.
Ugh, just predicted thinking this was going to May 3rd not the 1st.

Even if the 138 deaths in Ohio are one-off, the next two-day total should stay below 63 if Ohio is to remain below 1000. This has been the case in 3 of last 9 two-day totals (earlier data has less relevance, I'd say), and these included the weekend. Small data revisions (below 10 deaths) would not affect this.

It looks that the death spike in Ohio is a one time correction - they just caught up with deaths unreported for weeks: only 75 from 138 are from the LAST THREE days. Staying (cautiously) the course as my model still gives the count under 1,000 in this case. "And the number of deaths from the highly infectious disease raced past 900 with the addition of 138 more deaths – an apparent daily record – to raise the statewide toll to 937 Ohioans lost to COVID-19. … Death reporting does not represent the numbers who died the prior day, as some deaths date back weeks and were not reported immediately to the state health department. But figures showed 75 of the deaths reported Wednesday occurred in the past three days." https://www.dispatch.com/news/20200429/coronavirus-in-ohio-case-numbers-deaths-going-wrong-way-franklin-county-now-has-most-infections
Ohio had a big spike in deaths today

Updating from 0/0/0/79/21. We reached 13 today: CA, CT, FL, GA, IN, IL, LA, MA, MD, MI, NJ, NY, PA. New probabilities for states still in play with today's data: CO: 1%
Down from 2%. Now needs more than 14% daily growth two days in a row. Normally I'd say 0% but the data entry for CO is clearly messed up. One day you get 5%, the next 17%, then 1%... it's been like this since the beginning. OH: 80%
Big jump in OH today with 138 new deaths, or 17% growth in one day, which surprised everyone (but surprised me a little less than most ;-) ). Now we are at 937 and need just 3.3% daily growth two days in a row, and OH has never seen daily growth less than that on a weekday. (OH also suffers from day-of-the-week reporting idiosyncrasies.) The numbers alone make me want to say 90% chance at least, but other states have revised their deaths down after big increases due to clerical errors being fixed. TX: 0% (unchanged)
WA: 0% (unchanged) Assuming states independent I get: < 13 states: no chance
13 states: 20%
14 states: 79%
15 states: 1%
> 15 states: no chance
Ohio had a bad day -- now at 937.  It wouldn't take much to put OH over 1000.

Those making forecasts earlier today are at a disadvantage in that OH reported an unusually larger number later today that may influence some of your models. It certainly made a difference to my model.

Previous forecast: 
95%
5% The total is now 13. Ohio reported 138 deaths today. That is a huge increase compared to their average, and very unexpected. It could be an anomaly. They now have a total of 937 deaths. With two days to go, they need an average of 31.5 deaths per day. That is lower than their 7 days running average and much lower when you exclude weekends.
Going into today Ohio needed 200 deaths over 3 days to be 14 and it reported 138 deaths just today.

Georgia (contrary to my belief) and Maryland (as projected) have hit >1000 deaths, bringing the current total up to 11. Other climbing states (Washington, Colorado, Texas) have not made enough progress to make me think that they will flip over 1000 before May 1st.

Practically at 13 now.  For more than 13, it would require Ohio to have over 66 deaths per day to exceed 1000.  Yesterday was Ohio's deadliest day at 50 deaths (https://www.news5cleveland.com/news/local-news/investigations/tuesday-was-ohios-most-deadly-day-yet-in-covid-19-crisis).  I don't think that is very likely.

12 is certain. Using my normal calc I get 53% chance of 14 or higher. My mid-point estimate is 14.6.  12+ 100%
13+ 83%
14+ 53% However, subjectively I'm adjusting that probability down to 15%. I think my model relies too heavily on the a percentage of new cases converting into deaths and there isn't enough time. CTP has a history of upward adjustments so that's why I'm not going to 10%

Are or will hit 1000 (CA, Connecticut, Illinois, Louisiana, MA, Michigan, NJ, NY, Florida, Pennsylvania, Georgia, maryland) possible (Indiana). I will therefore update my forecast too between 12 and 13 states, as I do not see anymore that can suddenly go over with only  2 days to go.

Currently, there are 12 states that have more than 1,000 death. Indiana is likely to over 1,000 as it is currently sitting at 992 and it will make it the 13th state. However, the next closest is Ohio, which is currently sitting at a bit less than 800. Unless there is a major rise in cases, it will likely stay below 1,000 below May 1.

Updating from 0/0/0/68/32. We are at 12 today: CA, CT, FL, GA, IL, LA, MA, MD, MI, NJ, NY, PA. New probabilities for states still in play with today's data: CO: 2%
Down from 10% as growth was low the past 2 days, and these final days matter the most. Would be 0% except there was GIANT growth over the weekend so it looks like they have problems with measurement or reporting. IN: 80% (unchanged)
Indiana has ~270 people on ventilators, and at least another ~270 in the ICU but not on ventilators. We have 99 to go in Indiana, which again is a smallish fraction of those in serious condition, but now we have only 3 days to go. Currently we need just 3.5% daily growth, which is far below average growth over the past week; and in Indiana we have a pattern of slower (reported) growth on Sun and Mon, maybe because info isn't being entered on weekends or something. So in the next 3 days we'd expect especially high growth. OH: 25%
Down from 35%. The fact that it still has 201 to go and only 3 days makes me want to put it at 10% or lower. But it "only" needs 7.7% daily growth now, which has definitely happened on Wed-Fri, as late as last week. (Ohio also has a day-of-the-week effect on its reported growth.) From 17-20 April there were huge daily jumps in positive cases, even accounting for number of tests performed. It could be that these will come due now, ~2 weeks later. I predict OH will reach 1,000 at most 3 days after the deadline. TX: 0%
Down from 3%. Needs over 13% 3 days in a row now. Only one day in the last 2 weeks has seen growth > 13%. WA: 0% (unchanged) Assuming states are independent, I get: < 12 states: no chance
12 states: 15%
13 states: 64%
14 states: 21%
> 14 states: no chance

Maryland is likely to hit 1k, Indiana may be just shy.
Hitting 14 will depend on Ohio, which is projected to hit 1k after the 1st except in the worst cast scenario. https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-us-cases.html#states
https://covid19.healthdata.org/united-states-of-america
Currently 12 states, which looks like the probable correct answer.  Hedging a bit more on >13.

Changing from 
79%
21% Georgia, Indiana, and Maryland will almost certainly pass 1000 deaths, making the total 13.  In my opinion, Ohio is the only other state with a chance. They need an average of 62 deaths per day. That is a big jump relative to their last couple of weeks and short term trajectory.
We are almost there now. I could envision 15 or more with the recent re-openings in several states.
Practically at 13 now, close to more by May 1 (https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/us/).
Exactly 13. Very close. Worst point: it´s not getting better as fast as I expected (and hoped).
Best case scenario, Georgia will barely hit 1k. Major risk is an interruption in reporting. A "pop" in mortality rate among multiple states is possible, but ever so slightly less likely.

Easing of state-mandated quarantine measures may increase infection. Though states with higher population density and residents per household are experiencing higher rates of infection than less densely populated one, that does not prohibit interstate travel from shifting those numbers.
Flipping again, will be 12 or 13 I think
Nine states are reporting over 1000 deaths as of today according to IMHE model and statistics.

As of today, 9 states have already reported more than 1000 cases (New York, Michigan, Illinois, New Jersey, California, Conneticut, Massachussets, Florida & Louisiana).
Georgia has 912 confirmed deaths, but due to the nearly linear nature of the current spread I think it will fall just shy of 1000 cases, unless there's a small spike, which is possible.
Maryland has 910 confirmed deaths, and has been rising rapidly (>50 deaths a day) for the past few days, so that will likely top 1000 by May 1st.
Indiana has also seen a climb towards 1000, and I prjoct it will be very close to 1000 on May 1st. It's nearly a coin toss on whether it will cross the threshold.
Other climbing states (Washington, Colorado, Texas) are too far removed from the threshold to cross it in the remaining four days, unless an unforeseen increase occurs.
Therefore, I expect the total amount of states to be between 10 and 12. 10 I believe to be the likeliest number, followed by 11. 12 or higher will become increasingly unlikely.

GA: 99% (unchanged)
IN: 80% (up from 70% as it stayed on track)

TX: 3% (down from 15% as growth has been below needed for last few days. Now needs 9%/day)
WA: 0% (unchanged) Assuming states are independent, I get: < 11 states: no chance
11 states: 1%
12 states: 16%
13 states: 51%
14 states: 29%
15 states: 3%
> 15 states: no chance
reasonably expected not to spike dramatically over the next week
Based on CDC reports of state deaths as of 26 April and accompanying trends for states.

Certain: NY, NJ, MI, LA, IL, MA, CA, CT, PA, FL
Probable: GA, MD
Possible: IN, WA, OH
10 states currently, five more are within 100-200 of 1000 deaths.

29% The numbers were low as expected.  Georgia seems to be slowing down substantially, making the 11-13 bracket more likely.

Ten states are already over 1000 COVID-19 deaths, with two other states close to the mark, with another week to go. As the deaths are typically clustered, if another institution (care home for example) becomes infected within the next week, there is potential for additional states to increase their death rate before May 1st, although it appears unlikely.
10 total as of today with Georgia about to reopen economy hovering at 897
From the latest data, WA and TX are moved to 0%, MD and OH to 75%, IN to 50%, and CO to 25%, resulting in 39% of having 3 or more states over the threshold, in additional to the 11 certain states.

Open source already has 10 states with 1000 or more ruling out the first 3 categories.  Georgia is at 912, Maryland is at 910, and Indiana is at 813. Georgia needs 22 deaths per day to reach 1000, Maryland needs 23 deaths per day to reach 1000, Indiana needs 46 deaths per day to reach 1000. These death rates are all very likely look at at state's daily report death trends.  No other state's death volume and rate appear to be able to close to 1000 before 1 May. That said, NY State's recent decision to recount COVID19 deaths could adjust all these numbers upward if the CDC decides to follow suite (which I doubt for political reasons.) All data from https://coronavirus.1point3acres.com/en
Six days to go. What a horrible topic for a forecast.

Maryland with substantial increases, will likely surpass Georgia regarding the number of deaths tomorrow (as counted by the COVID Tracking Project) as it already has by counting of worldometers [1]. Increasing probability for the x>13 bracket. [1] https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/us/

10 states have now reached 1,000 deaths, and Georgia is very close. That gives us at least 11. The remaining states to watch are:
- Maryland: 90%
- Indiana: 60%
- Colorado: 20%. I hadn't considered it before, but they had a significant spike to 674 deaths.

If the trends continue, it will be 12, with Maryland and Georgia joining the ones, which already crossed the threshold. Indiana will be close,  between 900 and 1000, but most probably will not make it above 1,000. Regardless, there is a small possibility that it will be the 13th, making the 4th bucket full. Or my logistic models are wrong... ;)

Worldmeters.info (https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/us/) tracks very closely with the data on covidtracking.com, but the state information is organized in a chart for easy digestion. Near the end of day Sat 25 April, 10 States have 1,000 confirmed deaths: NY, NJ, MI, MA, IL, CT, PA, LA, CA, FL. 4 more states are relatively close to the 1,000 mark: GA (907), MD (875), IN (785), WA (738), with Maryland having 50 or more deaths today and yesterday. Indiana will also likely be close to 1,000 deaths as of 1 May 2020.

Texas and Washington look unlikely to reach 1000. Maryland, Indiana, and Georgia should all reach 1000. Making the total 13. However, the typically low weekend numbers could make this less likely. Colorado had a surprising jump in deaths today, up 122. If this continues then it could easily reach 1000. Ohio had a decline in numbers but could also easily reach 1000 if their numbers grow. Zooming out on today's numbers, you can see an expected pattern of growth across most of these states. It will be difficult to determine which ones will pass the threshold before the deadline.  Due to this apparent pattern, I'm increasing the chances of 'over 13'  to 29%, from 7%.
considering the current protests and rush to reopen some states, death cases are likely to rise in some numerous states
Backing off slightly until i see today's official numbers

As of 25 Apr already 10 states already report over 1000 deaths.  GA is the next closest at 899.  Historical data from GA shows average deaths per day are about 30: https://dph.georgia.gov/covid-19-daily-status-report (Figure "Daily Average (previous 7 days) of COVID-19 Deaths" is useful).  MD is next closest with 798 deaths, and averaging about 40/day (https://coronavirus.maryland.gov/); IN has 741 averaging 30/day (https://www.coronavirus.in.gov/).  WA (723 deaths) has been well below 20/day (https://www.doh.wa.gov/Emergencies/Coronavirus)
Just added some percentages to the 11 < x < 13 bracket.

There are currently 10 states with more than 1,000 cases - California
- Connecticut
- Florida
- Illinois
- Louisiana
- Massachusetts
- Michigan
- New Jersey
- New York
- Pennsylvania It's less than a week until the question will be resolved. I expect Georgia (as of today with 899 deaths) to exceed the number of 1,000 deaths. Maryland with currently 798 deaths is after Georgia the state closest to the threshold, followed by Indiana (741), Washington (723), Ohio (690) and Colorado (674). Data quality may be an issue here, however, I don't expect dramatic improvements until the beginning of May.

When I made this prediction, there were already 9 states over 1,000. 2 states were less than 200 away, so there is a chance they don't cross 1,000, but a big chance they do. If they do, it puts me in the 11-13 range. There are 3 more that are a little over a few hundred away, so it is certainly possible they cross 1,000, so I gave them some probability as well. since the curve hasn't flattened, I think most likely we end up at 11-13 states
Numbers in Ohio, Maryland, and Indiana all decreased despite more testing. Plus, the weekend is coming up, which usually means lower numbers.
based on expectation and number and states
Now at 10 with 6 or 7 close to going over 1000 at current daily rate in 7 days
Will Maryland join the club? Hope not.

Total is at 9. 8 days to go. OH's spike in new cases (still) looks like an actual spike, but OH's numbers seem suspect. Have to see what happens tomorrow. IN remains borderline, but has started adding presumptive cases to the death count, which will cause it to be higher. Both IN and OH remain borderline as cases 13 and 14. MD, GA, FL are sure things.

9 states have already passed 1000 deaths. Florida and Georgia will almost certainly follow them before 1 May. Maryland, Indiana, and Ohio also have a very strong chance. Ohio needs 43 more per day on average. Today they got 46
Maryland - 32. 117
Indiana - 37. 45 Only 2 out of those 3 could pass the threshold due to low weekend numbers. However, if the growth rate in deaths continues speeding up it may push all 3 over 1000.

At 9 today and will likely tip to 10 with FL at 960. Projections for the closest candidates:
Georgia - 1300 (900-2500) *
Washington - 775 (700-967)
Maryland - 1060 (730-2000) 
Indiana - 908 (690-1500)

Virginia - 590 (380-1200) I feel confident that Georgia will hit 1k (and celebrate by opening up for business tomorrow,) and Maryland is a hard "maybe" leaning toward yes. As I said earlier, Washington is pretty firmly a "no." 
Unless things get crazy in Indiana, it'll likely miss the cut. We may be surprised, just note that the high end estimates are how bad it can get; but I don't weigh those figures too heavily. It looks like we'll hit 12 states; 11 at minimum. (Note: Who knows! We've been surprised before.) https://covid19.healthdata.org/united-states-of-america

Was shaped a bit by community forecast yesterday, I actually don't believe more than 13 will happen. Most likely is 11 or 10 in my opinion (current 9 + FL for sure, Georgia 80:20). Giving outlier >13 5% since different states topping it are correlated and underestimating dynamic of remaining days might make me wrong here. Naively multiplying my odds would give <1%.

Rationales for each state in the code comments. Here are the chances I get, rounded to nearest percent: < 11 states: no chance
11 states: 5%
12 states: 24%
13 states: 41%
14  states: 26%
15  states: 4%
> 15 states: no chance # A random variable is a dict of values to probabilities
from collections import defaultdict def SumRV(x,y):
..sum = defaultdict(float)
..for value_x,probability_x in x.items():
....for value_y,probability_y in y.items():
......sum[value_x + value_y] += probability_x * probability_y
..return sum CO = { 0: 0.97, 1: 0.03 }
FL = { 0: 0.0, 1: 1.0 }
GA = { 0: 0.01, 1: 0.99 } # Indiana has ~330 people on ventilators and another ~300 in ICU beds
# (on top of ventilator people). Currently at 661 deaths, need 339 to go.
# That's 53% of those in in serious condition. Heard somewhere that survival
# rate on ventilators is 1/7. Even if it's 1/5 that would put us at 925, and the
# non-ventilator ICU death rate would only need to be 25%.
IN = { 0: 0.3, 1: 0.7 } # Currently 1432 hosp. Total hosp is 3325 so current is 43%.
# Total who have left hosp (one way or another) is 1893, and 
# 631 dead, so death rate is 1/3 (doesn't matter if dead were hosp). 
# That extrapolates to 477 more dead, assuming all die or recover 
# within 9 days (seems reasonable), putting us at ~1100 dead. 
MD = { 0: 0.35, 1: 0.65 } # Hosp 5-day trend up to 22 Apr is similar to that of [13 Apr, 22 Apr]
# So expect about as many deaths in next 9 days as previous 9 days 
# Puts us at ~950. Can't say at this point 
OH = { 0: 0.5, 1: 0.5 } # Texas new cases graph looks ~linear for the past several days.
# So we should expect about as many deaths in next 9 days as in
# past 9 days. This puts us well below 1,000, around 800. 
# There are 1678 currently hospitalized, though this isn't
# broken down into ICU beds, ventilators etc. We'd need ~28% of
# those to die, which is roughly in line with Maryland rate I
# guess. Not sure how to reconcile.
TX = { 0: 0.85, 1: 0.15 } # WA is pretty clearly over its peak in all curves -- daily
# new cases, daily deaths, daily hospitalizations. Not going 
# to go over 1,000.
WA = { 0: 1.0, 1: 0.0 } states = [FL, GA, CO, IN, MD, OH, TX, WA] globalDist = { 0: 1, 1: 0}
for state in states:
..globalDist = SumRV(globalDist,state) print globalDist

Total is still at 9.  9 days to go. OH's spike in new cases looks like an actual spike and not a big jump to a new higher level. Have to see what happens tomorrow. IN looks a little better. New cases there have been flat-ish for over 2 weeks. Both IN and OH remain borderline as cases 13 and 14.  MD, GA, FL still look like sure things.

What has become clear in Europe  is that deaths in nursing homes etc can have an enormous impact on the number of deaths. These follow a little after initial outbreaks but because of the circumstances are often almost explosive. 1/3 to 1/2 a ward dies in days. Another factor is that the excessive deaths show an underreporting in probable covid deaths that is reduced when testing is increased like now is happening. There for chances are the number of deaths might increase.  9 states have reported more than 1000 deaths according to cdc. But Florida Texas and Connecticut have significant lower deaths to cases ratios so they might increase significantly in the coming week. The relaxation of lock down measures will have some effect, but it will take 2-4 weeks for people to start die, so that will not be measured within the timeframe.

See below.  The only caveat is that some at-risk states are reopening.  This increase the odds of additional states reaching 1000 deaths; however, I have read it normally takes 5 to 6 days to experience symptoms; another 5 to 6 days for them to become serious; and, 2 to 3 days for  death to follow.  Therefore, the  openings should not happen soon enough to affect the already gruesome outcome.

Today's numbers show rate of growth is slowing.
Already there:  NY, NJ, MI, MA, PA, IL, CT, LA, CA   = 9
Nearly there: FL and GA= 2 
Possible:  (I just played around with the average growth rates that seemed most relevant for each state; e.g., for states with sharp changes, I emphasized more recent averages. I  used averages over longer range if numbers were fairly constant.) 
IN (630 deaths; average growth rate last 5 days: 5.78% =1,105; last 3 days = 4.55%;  it would have be at least 4.78 % for  cases to reach 1000; so 63-35% no)
MD (584 deaths; average growth last 10 days 11.04; last 5 days: 8.34 % need 5.5% to reach 1000, but knock out some outliers and growth falls to about 5 percent. 50-50%.
WA (652 deaths; average growth rate last 10 days 3.12%; needs 4.4% to reach 1000.  5% percent chance)
OH  (557 deaths; average growth rate last 10 days 8.54 %; but 7.51 and falling last 6 days; needs 6 % to reach 1000;  85% likely.)
TX (517 deaths; average growth rate last 10 days 7.41% but only 4.84% last 5 days; needs 6.9% to reach 1000; 10 percent chance.)
The rest are so far away that it is not worth computing their numbers.  Finally, 9 already there, 2 all but certain, 1  likely and 1 close to even odds.  Thus, 11 min, 13 max, with 12 the most likely outcome.

Are or will hit 1000 (CA, Connecticut, Illinois, Louisiana, MA, Michigan, NJ, NY, Florida, Pennsylvania, ) Very likely (Georgia), likely (Indiana), possible (maryland, Ohio, Texas, Washington). Updating my forecasts. 
Following trends and death rates from Johns Hopkins and the CDC, it seems that the death rate and infection rate has not yet crested in many states, principally Florida, Georgia, Texas, and Indiana.  For Florida, if the death rates remain constant based on current US and global trends, it seems highly probable that they will cross 1000. In Georgia, if the infection and death rates remain constant for the next 10 days it seems probable that they will also cross 1000 deaths. In Texas, the current death rates are low but the trend seems to show acceleration in reporting, particularly in rural areas. The question is whether that acceleration will continue to increase in the next 10 days. It seems highly possible.  For Indiana and several other states, the question will be whether they begin to accelerate in the next few days.
Made my forecast less certain, as I based a lot of it on the IHME predictions which have been consistently overconfident with their 95% certainty intervals.

As of April 20, 9 states are over 1000.  Texas, Florida and Georgia are all over 500 deaths at this time.  Active cases in these states are all over 14,000.  So another 500 deaths each is a 3.6% death rate on active cases (lower than the current rate of a little over 5%).  10 days is enough time for the unfortunately result.  So this comes to 12 states. Then you have 4 states with around 10000 active cases (as of Apr 19) and close to 500 deaths to date.  Two of the four would give us 14 states.  There is some chance that we will not reach the 14 states in the remaining 10 days (which would be good news) and that is the reason I have not said 100% more than 13.

Difficulty level increasing. Case In Point - they are not reporting their prison system numbers (385) in the state count and at least TWO 800 test a day machines are coming on line today so a heavy surge is developing.

Revised down as it is now very possible to be 12-13 states Instead. As we approach the end of the month, One thing I should draw attention to is the delay in publication of deaths. From "More Info" tab, you can see that 1 May data will be released on May 4th, so a 3 day lag. Hence As i view the data now on April 20th, There is actually 13 days of deaths remaining, not 10. This will become extremely important as we approach the completion date.  Early on there was also lots of deaths that were not classified as Covid-19 related because they were not tested. As we are still seeing a ramp up of testing availability, as well as more awareness of testing deceased persons. There is also a huge blowup in European news this week about the full extent of carehome deaths and how they are not being tested or reported. This may well filter into US thinking in the coming 2 weeks, and I believe this is a possible tailwind to the death total entering the last 2 weeks of April. Here are my thoughts from April 20th: 9 are over 1000  Florida is 773 and doubling every 10 days. Even with a steep decceleration, they will pass 1000. for me this is very near 100%, so 10 are 99% chance for me personally.  Washington and Wisconsin now appears near 0% chance, which leaves 17 states (10/17) For remaining 7 states important metrics are deaths, doubling rate, but also date of lockdown, to estimate seeded infections. From looking at European data, daily deaths seem to peak 3-4 weeks after full lockdown. The extreme lag time in my opinion is the infections from the day before lockdown proceeding to infect the rest of household over the following week. Maryland: 486 deaths, current doubling every 7 days. large gatherings restricted March 16th. Full lockdown March 30th, exactly 3 weeks ago, so i will assume Maryland is approaching peak daily deaths. Even making April 20th the daily peak has the death total surpassing 1000 by May 4th data, so this for me is, conservatively, a 90% chance. Georgia: 682 deaths, current doubling every 11 days. "shelter in place" order implemented April 3rd. A relatively late lockdown date conflicts with a long doubling time. I believe this would be close if not for the total deaths already being fairly high, at nearly 700. Deaths becoming apparent in the next few days will have been seeded before lockdown, meaning i doubt we are past the daily peak ( contrary to the data i know). For these reasons i believe georgia to be ~95% to pass 1000 deaths by May 4th data. Ohio: 471 deaths doubling every 8 days. bars and eateries closed March 15th, shelter in place March 22nd. A very early lockdown date, conflicted by a steep death rate. I believe this early Lockdown means we are already at peak daily deaths in the state, and could see this metric fall swiftly. That being said, it is unlikely to deccelerate fast enough, given the 13 days that are left. I have this at 80% chance. Indiana: 562 deaths doubling every 9 days. schools, bars and restaurants closed March 16th, shelter in place order March 24th. Another early lockdown date, Meaning we should be at or past peak daily deaths. This is extremely close to call, a classic "50/50" for me. Texas: 503 deaths doubling every 9 days. a "patchwork" of local regulations, making this hard to work out. anything but a total state lockdown means a serious exponential acceleration could appear anywhere in the state however, which adjusts the probability a lot. This coupled with state protests arguing for a reopening (shows public sentiment and therefore will to abide by lockdown rules) means unfortunately I think we will see some serious numbers out of Texas, and I believe it to be 80% chance to reach 1000 deaths by May 4th data.  Virginia: 277 deaths doubling every 6 days. Shelter in place March 30th. We should be at the peak daily deaths, but the doubling time is still virulent, makes Virginia a possible, despite its small death total.It would have to double twice, at current doubling time that would take 11 days, however the acceleration SHOULD be slowing as we are 3-4 weeks from lockdown date. Another tough one to call, 35% for me currently but this probability will be all over the place on a daily basis as new data emerges. Colorado: 421 deaths doubling every 13 days. bars and restaurants closed March 1st, Schools March 18th, stay at home order March 26th. Early closure dates across the board, already a very slow doubling time, and should deccelerate further. At current doubling rate Colorado would fall just under 1000 deaths in 14 days, and rate should be deccelerating. The only way it can go over is if a cluster of deaths at a carehome or prison emerge, or some large unseen factor that we cannot predict. I give Colorado a 5% chance.  To summarise: Florida 99%
Maryland 90%
Georgia 95%
Texas 80%
Ohio 80%
Indiana 50%
Virginia 35%
Colorado 5%
Washington <1%
Wisconsin <1%

8 states have already passed 1000 deaths.  There are 9 more states which I think are at a ‘high risk’ of passing 1000 deaths by the 1st of May. If you calculate the 10-day running average of deaths for each state, times this by 12 then add this to the current total you get:  Pennsylvania - 52.7| 632.4 + 836 = 1468.4
Florida - 44.5| 534 + 754 = 1288
Georgia - 29.1| 349.2 + 673 = 1022.2
Indiana - 34.2| 410.4 + 545 = 955.4
Maryland - 33.9| 406.8 + 463 = 869.8
Texas - 27.6| 331.3 + 453 = 784.2
Ohio - 24.9| 298.8 + 451 = 749.8
Washington* - 18.7| 224.4 + 603 = 827.4
Colorado - 21.2| 254.4 + 391 = 645.4 *Only 6-day average for Washington because the data is not very consistent on previous days. If the current trends continue; Pennsylvania, Florida, and Georgia will all pass 1000 deaths. However, it will not be a linear curve. The future results will depend upon a variety of factors. The most important one is - which section of the curve each state is at.  The average time it took states which have already passed 1000 deaths to get from 600 to 1000 deaths was around 5.5 days (not including New York). They also took an average of around 7.5 days to get from 200 to 600 deaths (again not including New York).  Pennsylvania is the only ‘high risk’ state which took less than 7.5 days to get from 200 deaths to 600 deaths… Pennsylvania - 7 days
Florida - 11 days 
Georgia - 12 days 
Indiana - 10 days since 200, still 55 away
Maryland - 7 days since 200, still 137 away
Texas - 9 days since 200, still 147 away 
Ohio - 10 days since 200, still 149 away
Washington - 20 days
Colorado - 9 days since 200, still 209 away From 600, It took Pennsylvania 3 days to reach 800 deaths. It’s going to take Florida 1 or 2 more days to reach 800 deaths, 4 or 5 days in total. From this, I’m relatively confident that Pennsylvania and Florida will reach 1000 deaths before may the 1st. This brings the total to 10 states. If Georgia continues at its 10-day average, it will go from 600 to 800 deaths in 6 or 7 days total. Therefore, it may reach 800 deaths in 4 or 5 days. If Georgia follows a similar curve to other states, it should reach 1000 deaths sooner than the 1st of May.  If Indiana continues at its 10-day average, it will reach 800 deaths in around 7 to 8 more days. However this will probably happen sooner, just pushing it over the 1000 mark if it follows the curve.  Maryland could reach 1000 deaths if its average rate increases. Again, following the likely curve, I believe there is a 45% chance of this happening.  Washington seems to be a wildcard, extremely difficult to judge without more data. With the information we have I don’t think it will reach 1000 deaths.  All the other states will probably not reach 1000 deaths by May the 1st either, bringing the total to 12. However, Close attention to each one is needed.  For each state to reach 1000 deaths there average per day needs to be: Pennsylvania - 13.7
Florida - 20.5
Georgia - 27.3
Indiana - 37.9
Maryland - 44.8
Texas - 45.6
Ohio - 45.8
Washington - 33.1
Colorado - 50.8 Criticism is very welcome!

Minor update based on figures for 17th.

As of 4/17, there are 6 states with >1000 deaths: IL (1072), LA (1156), MA (1245), MI (2093), NJ (3518), NY (12192).
To project deaths in 2 weeks, I made several assumptions:
1) For states that report ventilated patients, I assumed that 70% will die in the next 2 weeks based on published estimates ranging between 55-80%. Also, average ICU length of stay is around 2-3 weeks.
2) For states that don't report vent stats, I estimated that the ICU mortality would be slightly lower (50%) since hospitals in most states are still below capacity and may still accept non-intubated patients in their ICUs.
3) For states that did not report ICU or vent stats, I estimated that the overall hospital mortality rate would be 10%, since these patients are moderately-severely ill.
Using this algorithm, I identified an additional 3 states likely to exceed 1000 deaths:
CA (1393-1674)
CT (1164)
PA (958-1180)
Therefore, I am very confident that 9 states will exceed 1000 deaths within 14 days. 
There remains a small possibility that localized outbreaks may develop. Nursing homes are very vulnerable. WA showed us that deaths can escalate quickly in this population due to patient factors (age, chronic illness) and staffing (high ratios, staff working in other nursing homes). I took CDC data from 2014 about the number of nursing home beds and calculated the potential deaths assuming a statewide 1% mortality rate among all NH patients. An additional 5 states met the 1000-death threshold: FL (83k NH beds; 1500 proj), GA (40k beds, 1017 proj), IN (60k beds, 1077 proj), OH (91k beds, 1299 proj), and TX (136k NH beds, 1750 proj). But I think the chances are very low in the next 2 weeks this will happen.

As of 5pm PT 15 April 2020, 5 states have crossed 1,000: Louisiana, Massachusetts, Michigan, New Jersey, New York. So that rules out the bottom bucket. There are 7 other states between 500 and 1000: Connecticut, California, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Pennsylvania, Washington. I consider it basically a sure thing that the number of deaths in every state will more than double in two weeks. The exception may be states that have been facing the crisis for longer and thus have had time to learn how serious it is, and act. As far as I know, among the 7 this is CA and WA. However, CA is at 821 and there's no way we don't go over 1,000 in 16 days. But WA is at 541 and the daily increase has been around 3.5%-4.5% daily for the past ~10 days [1]. WA is not great at publishing data (there are several days with "no deaths" and then a day with lots of deaths) but if you interpolate it it's remarkably consistent in the last 10 days at 3.5%-4.5%. At 4% daily increase (midpoint) starting from 541, we reach 1,013 on 1 May 2020. So to be conservative let's discard WA for now. Still that leaves us with 6 more states reaching 1,000.  So that puts us at 11, ruling out all but the top 2 buckets. I just looked at the crowd forecast and top two buckets are 38% combined. What?? Anyway, let's look at the other side. To be conservative, let's say no state has deaths growing at > 10% / day. That means any state with less than 217 deaths now, is not gonna reach 1,000. That rules out 34 of the 51 states. This is actually a robust calculation since there is a clean break around there: Virginia has 195, and the next one up is Colorado at 329, a lot higher. So Virginia and below need ~11%/day sustained growth to reach 1,000, whereas Colorado and above need ~7%. That leaves 5 states in play: Colorado, Indiana, Maryland, Ohio, Texas. Let's bring Washington back as it was on the fence. For a naive calculation let's say each has 50% independent chance to go over 1,000. What are the odds that 3 or more do? From elementary probability we know this is 42/64 ~ 66%. Now my big weakness is I am total crap at US geography. I have NO IDEA if these states are close to each other or correlated in some other way. And if I haven't learned US geography in the 10+ years I've lived here, I certainly won't start now. So I should de-extremize to 40/60 or something. On the other hand I shoved 34 states under the carpet over the 11%/day growth thing, and in the early stages of the pandemic you definitely see >20% rates of growth. So let's keep it at 34/66. @Anneinak @Datawick @JMR2017 [1] https://covidtracking.com/data/state/washington

Just looked at the most recent data, and found that I was probably in the weeds with my 22% chance of 5-7 states.

Projected to reach 1000 -- CA, CT, FL, IL, MA, PA
Projected to reach 750 to 960 -- GA, IN, MD, OH, TX, WA If the trend holds the answer will be 10.  If one of the near misses has a bad week the number will go over 10.  It's also possible that things improve in the six states that are headed towards 1000.  Let's all hope so, and also let's never forget that every number is a real person.

New York, New Jersey, Michigan and Louisiana are already over 1000.  So we have four states and counting.  Massachusetts and Illinois are close to 1000.  Illinois has 868 total deaths and 1189 patients in the ICU <https://covidtracking.com/data>, so that makes six states.  Indiana is only at 436 deaths, but has had 49 new deaths according to The COVID Tracking Project (arbiter of the challenge, see above link).  Indiana also has 721 in the ICU according to <https://covidtracking.com/data>. Maryland and Ohio are at 349 and 361, with 47 and 37 recent deaths, respectively.  They could have 1000 by May 1.  California is at 790, but seems to have hit a plateau.  One hotspot could push CA over 1000. More research into each state would produce more accurate results, but frankly I don't want to spend that much time on it.  So I'll make my guesses based on a quick survey of easily obtained data.  I'm overweighting 5-7 compared to the crowd, but basically agreeing with the crowd on 7-11 being correct (59% vs 57% for the crowd). The time duration of this challenge is short, so we had all better check the data every day.
Only 16 days to go in this grim question period.

There are currently four states above 1000. NY, NJ, MI, and LA.  MA and IL will go over 1000 in the next 3 days. That means we need two more states to push into the 8 to 10 inclusive group, or 5 to get into the 11-13 inclusive group. CA has 731 and is likely. They had 310 cases in the past week.
 PA is also very likely. They added 280 cases last week, bringing them to 571, and 106 today. That brought them to 696. So that's our 8. Are there 3 more? CT has 671 and is likely. (+ 69 today) 40 to 50 per day last week.
FL is possible, but I sense more under-counting here. They may have many deaths, but less than 1000 official deaths. (possible to likely) After that, it's GA, MD, TX, OH, IN. None of these are sure things. Given the large urban areas of Baltimore, Atlanta, Houston, Dallas, Cleveland, Indianapolis, any of them could take a bad turn. But they have a way to go.

Four states (NY, NJ, MI, LA) have deaths >1000 already, and one state (MA) is very close.  Therefore 0% for the less than 5 basket. Three states (IL,CA,CT) require a doubling time of <30 days to reach 1000 deaths.  Currently the doubling times are much smaller than 30 days.  It is very likely that they will get there, making a total of 8 states.  This makes the 5-7 baskets very unlikely. The next 4 states (PA, FL, WA, GA) require doubling times less than between 17 to 22 days.  It is likely at least half of these states will reach the target, making a total of at least 10 states, and up to 12 states. The rest of the states requires doubling times <12 days.  It is unlikely that more than one of them will reach the target.

Certain: NY, NJ, MI, LA
Probable: IL, MA, CA, CT, PA
Possible: FL, OH, CO, GA, IN, TX
My model predicts a 71% increase by that date. That puts 9 states over the mark. But, I have not modeled individual states' growth rates.

Definitely at least 7. Practically sure at least 8. But 9 or even 10 is quite possible. 11 is practically impossible with the current data. Which nicely fit 3rd bucket.  Can be wrong. Time will tell...

Drawing trendlines for each state and taking into account the difference in its average for the whole of april versus the last 5 days I categorized the states into three categories of "has or will happen", "uncertain" and "Possible, but unlikely". Which came to 8 states in the first category, 5 in the second and 2 in the last. Thus I am highly certaint that it will land between 9 and 12, but leaning closer to 9 or 10.
Based off of IHME's forecasts. Would place more confidence in 7-11 range but deaths may go unreported, or IHME might have been too optimistic in their last forecast.
States I think will reach 1000, or who are already there - CA, CO, FL, GA, IL, IN, LA, MA, MI, NJ, NY, PA, TX, WA States I am less certain on but exponential growth could get them there - OH, TN, VA

Certain: NY, NJ, MI
Probable: IL, LA, MA
Possible: CA, CT, FL, PA

There are 18 days until May 1st. I'm going to use the three states that have exceed 1,000 deaths as examples. NJ reached 1000 deaths on April 6th. 18 days prior, NJ was at 9 deaths. NY reached 1000 deaths  on March 30th, 18 days prior, on March 12th, they had 0 recorded deaths. Michigan reached 1000 deaths on April 9th. 18 days on prior, on March 22nd, they had 8 reported deaths.  Obviously, this is a somewhat biased sample - it's the set of states that had exploding death rates. This is due to their large (relatively urban) populations. But, it gives a sense of how quickly exponential growth can work. This example makes me lean, sadly, towards the larger values.  Looking through the list briefly there are a few states that will almost certainly reach the 1000 threshold. CA: 687 deaths 
MA: 884 deaths 
CN: 602 deaths
IL: 794 deaths
LA: 884 deaths I'm gonna put more thought into predicting the rest of the states, but it's pretty clear to me that this will certainly pass 5, and almost certainly pass 7, and most likely reach 10+.

Already there Ny, Nj, Mi.
Probably will get there: Il, La, Ma Pa
Maybe: Ca, Ct, Wa.

A bit of explanation behind my (probably wildely innacurate method, or rather heurisitc): first I decided to judge it by what states had the greatest cities by population density/size. and at first this seemed to fit (New Jersey, New York etc.), and also by what state had already hit past 500 deaths (so Illnois fits both of these profiles. However I abandoned the former rule of thumb due to the fact Texas and Conneticut both didn't fit this model. As someone with a lack of experience (and lack of education in proper statistcal analysis), I would greately appreciate any advice on how to improve the forecasting here (though I nonethelss will update this regularly due to being widly caught out in my predictions on how far this would go in the UK). Cheers.

https://coronavirus.1point3acres.com/
Took number of cases increasing in each state times death rate and added that to already dead. One could take rate of increase for each state but that is not necessarily a stable number. I am sure someone with better math skills could develop a clearer picture.

3 already there, 2 1/2 weeks to go. California, Massachusets and Louisianna already about 700 or higher and still growing, so first bucket almost impossible. Alltogether 10 states above 500 today. If number of deaths "only" doubled till end of month everywhere (that´s what I expect with the current trend), that would mean 10 maximum. Won´t grow the same way everywhere, and could grow more or less, so I see both buckets as equally likely for the moment. Will adjust every few days.

12 are all but guaranteed (already 400-500 deaths with expected doubling in 4-7 days). 13th and 14th requires decent spread in two of the remaining 30 States with 100-200 deaths. Given that lockdowns in most states have only recently been imposed, the exponential aspect of spread makes this event a 100% chance already.
Social distancing may not impact these numbers, but expertice, equipment, care and medications may make a difference. Assuming that over time best practices will emerge that make a difference.
Not many are within striking range of 1k deaths, and only 3 are currently above that level.
Judging by how it went in Bavaria, which had a quick sort of coordinated response plus a good universal healthcare system I cannot see how those states will not have 1000 cases of death by that time.
